So, here's a thought: with the focus on and addition of new plane-parts (giddygiddygiddy), have they also focused on the value of (space) planes in the game mechanics? As it stand now, you'll have to do a considerable amount of different tests and researches before ever having something resembling a plane. (Capsules strapped with canards do not count). Do you think there'll be a more direct availability to a space-plane development path now? Will there be more space-plane specific contracts such as gathering (specific) science from the atmosphere above specified locations or biomes?

As it is, I am one of those players that spend most of their time developing spaceplanes and experimenting with new wicked ways to improve them. Yet, for game-progress, their only real function so far is either as a testing bed for new(experimental) parts or (much later) as a SSTO/shuttle. Any thoughts on ways they might have tackled some of these problems?

Additionally, and I am pretty sure this will not be incorporated in this patch, is the 'debris' deletion which makes atmospheric flight a real pain in many situations. I love making dropships and exploring the planned by para-dropped supplies/vehicles/astronauts, but the fact that you'll have to remain within 2.5 km of your dropped cargo at risk of losing it is very painstaking. It does, of course , add another challenging element. But having to design your long range heavy-lifter with sharp turns in mind so that it doesn't lose its cargo after dropping is just limiting. any thoughts on this? Might the 64-bit version elevate some of these limitations?
Can't wait for 0.26!

I've been wanting them to rework the tech tree like that for a while now. We should be able to build a simple Mk1 atmospheric plane by tier 3. As it stands now you don't even get the basic jet engine and landing gear until tier 5. To me it just doesn't make sense for a civilization to discover flight only after launching rockets into space.
